text: PTX decreases LPS - induced NF-kappaB activation

Since phosphorylation leads to ubiquitination and degradation of <extra_id_0> I-kappaBalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and subsequent nuclear translocation of NF-kappaB , we first examined the effects of PTX on <extra_id_0> I-kappaBalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: Cytoplasmic <extra_id_0> I-kappaBalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> phosphorylation was markedly increased following LPS stimulation when compared to control ( 100 +/- 0 vs . 20 +/- 18 ; P < 0.05 ) .

text: The addition of PTX significantly downregulated LPS - induced <extra_id_0> I-kappaBalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> phosphorylation ( P = 0.02 ; Figure 2 )

text: In a similar fashion , nuclear NF-kappaB <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> phosphorylation was increased following LPS stimulation ( 100 +/- 0 vs . 38 +/- 20 ; P < 0.01 ) .

text: PTX similarly decreased LPS - induced NF-kappaB <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> nuclear phosphorylation , a marker of NF-kappaB activation and nuclear translocation ( 100 +/- 0 vs . 40 +/- 6 ; P =0.03 ; Figure 3A ) .

text: EMSAs were then performed to verify the PTX - induced alterations in nuclear phosphorylation resulted in similar effects on the DNA binding activity of NF-kappaB .

The addition of PTX to LPS - stimulated mononuclear cells resulted in comparable downregulation of DNA binding activity , similar to the observed downregulation of NF-kappaB phosphorylation ( Figure 3B ) .
